attributes.comment:
The key to adoption is simplicity See facebook(upload text, photo), youtube (upload a video), paypal(a gives $ to b), uber (pick a place to go), twitter(add a short text) This should solve for 90% of the cases. The rest can be custom built.

Similarly for maintaining provider directories, we should have a super simple way to a. identify the top impactful usecases: [provider, carrier, plans accepted]
b. credentialed to practice in a state
c. degree certificate etc

The top usecases should be insanely simple to accept by the provider and should work for 90% of the usecases. Often we make it all too complex for the majority in order to address the corner cases.

A. Carrier:
1. Each insurance company provides a list of state specific plans that they support

B. Provider:
[One time]
1. Creates an account using id.me or something similar. Their account identifies the state. Remember very few practice in multiple states
2. Uploads the credentials, degree etc.
3. Provides the phone #/email that he/she uses
[In-frequent]
4. On account creation, he/she selects the insurance company, and the plans supported.

C. Consumer[Patient]
As an end user, I can
a. Select my doctor, and check if my plan is supported.
b. If any change happens (like my plan is no longer supported or a new plan is accepted), I get a text/email message only if my plan is not supported

On a regular basis,
1. Everytime the insurance company adds/removes a plan(rare), the provider gets a text/email to which the provider accepts/denies being part of the plan.
This can be sent to the provider 2x a week to avoid being a nuisance.

2. Everytime a provider decides to drop off/add into a plan, he/she logs in and selects it to add or remove the plan

3. Provider can also say here that they accept new patients or not. The subscribed patients get a notification

Distribution: give an incentive to create and spread
1. Doctors get $500 if they create an account and update it.
2. They can share with their colleagues and get $250 (They should have an incentive to spread the info).
With one million providers => cost $750M

Misc:
1. Anyone who finds the data wrong gets $25 paid by the provider/carrier who entered the wrong data. IF not $, they get a "Thank you certificate" - some form of recognition. No penalties over $100
2. Make this data downloadable for use by the community. Do not charge.
3. Allow a github community to build tools around it. Provide the key contributors excellent recognition.

Expand the above for provider systems(hospitals etc). They have an IT staff and can follow a similar approach

PS: I will be glad to build it at a low cost if one is really interested. Anyway that is not the intent! Key is that it needs to be simple
